sect1.title: Stylesheet Customization
sect1.para: Ok, now you're nearly a docbook guru? You want to get right down to the entrails of the machinery? OK, hop on and enjoy the ride! Here are a few notes on how you should go about customizing the output. That means, changing how the pdf and html are written.

sect2.title: File hierarchy
sect2.para: The files for configuration are the following:

listitem.para: common.xsl This is where all the common specifications are made, ie those that go and in pdf and in html.
pdf.xsl This is where all the pdf specific customizations are made
html.xsl This is where most html specific customizations are made.
onehtml.xsl and chunkedhtml.xsl, specifics for html, the former on one page, "chunked", one file per chapter, for the latter.
ProActive.css Which is yet another extra layer on top of the html output.

sect2.title: What you can change
sect2.para: Basically, in the customization layers, you have full control (just do what you want). The only thing is that each block (template, variable...) should be described by a comment. That will help later users. As customization can get cryptic, make a special effort!

sect2.title: The Bible
sect2.para: The book you want to have with you is the following: "DocBook XSL: The Complete Guide", Third Edition, by Bob Stayton, online version at http://www.sagehill.net.

Have a look at the index if you just want to change a little something in the customization. Parse through it at least once if you intend to do some heavy editing. I have found everything I needed in this book, but sometimes in unexpected sections.

listitem.para: Ensure no dead links exist (easy with wget --spider OR http://www.dead-links.com/ for html, harder for the pdf).
Use this info (google Re: Extending ulink Warren Young) to specialize ulinks in pdf/html [is it needed?].
Create an index, and put the main words in it
Images should be centered. Code borders should only wrap code, not from left to right margin.
All important code examples should be wrapped in EXAMPLE tags
